Caption: Koel (female) [Eudynamys scolopaceus]
Description: Salim Ali and S. Dillon Ripley note that the female is (above) “dark brown, profusely white-spotted and barred. Tail-feathers and wing-quills barred with white”, and (below) “white; spotted on chin, throat and foreneck, barred on rest of underparts with blackish.” Interestingly Koels are known for their habit of laying eggs in the nests of crows. The male Koel is described by Ali and Ripley as “glistening metallic black all over, with yellowish green bill and crimson eyes.”
